case_name: Ram Sewak Yadav v. Hussain Kamil Kidwai

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1064 of 1963 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1064 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated July 23, 1963 of Allahabad High Court Lucknow Bench in First Civil Appeal No. 11 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 23, 1963, of the Allahabad High Court  Lucknow Bench  in First Civil Appeal No. 11 of 1963.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on January 17, 1964 by SHAH J.

anchor.surface_text: January 17, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH J.-At the general elections held in February 1962,

facts.text: General elections held in February 1962 to the House of the People from Barabanki single-member constituency with five candidates contesting.

anchor.surface_text: At the general elections held in February 1962, five candidates contested the election to the House of the People from the Barabanki single-member constituency.

facts.text: Ram Sewak Yadav secured the highest number of votes at counting and was declared elected.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Ram Sewak Yadav-who will be referred to as Yadav- was at the counting of votes found to have secured the highest number of votes and he was declared elected.

facts.text: Hussain Kamil Kidwai submitted election petition on April 6, 1962 to Election Commission declaring Yadav's election void and himself duly elected.

anchor.surface_text: Hussain Kamil Kidwai-hereinafter called Kidwai-who was one of the candidates at the election submitted a petition on April 6, 1962, to the Election Commission for an order declaring the election of Yadav void and for an order that he  Kidwai  be declared duly elected.

facts.text: Election Tribunal Lucknow dismissed the petition.

anchor.surface_text: The Election Tribunal, Lucknow, to which the petition was referred for trial dismissed the petition.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court reversed Tribunal's order and remanded proceedings with direction to allow inspection of ballot papers.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal to the High Court of Allahabad the order passed by the Election Tribunal was reversed and the proceedings were remanded for trial with a direction, among others, that the Tribunal do give reasonable opportunity to both the parties to inspect the ballot papers and other connected papers.

facts.text: Kidwai alleged improper reception, refusal and rejection of votes materially affecting election.

anchor.surface_text: The principal grounds set up by Kidwai in support of his petition were-  1  that there had been improper reception, refusal and rejection of votes at the time of counting, and in consequence thereof the election was materially affected

facts.text: Kidwai alleged discrepancies between total votes in Form 16 and Form 20.

anchor.surface_text: 2  that there were discrepancies between the total number of votes mentioned in Form 16 and Form 20

facts.text: Kidwai alleged tendered votes wrongly rejected by returning officer materially affecting election.

anchor.surface_text: 3  that the tendered votes were wrongly rejected by the returning officer and on that account the election was materially affected

facts.text: Kidwai alleged polling officers at station No. 29 Majgawan in Bhitauli Unit and Kursi station did not give ballot papers to voters.

anchor.surface_text: 4  that at the polling station No. 29, Majgawan in Bhitauli Unit and Kursi polling station in Kursi Assembly Unit, the polling officers did not give ballot papers to the voters

facts.text: Kidwai alleged counting of votes of Bhitauli Assembly Unit continued till 8-30 p.m. in insufficient light despite protest.

anchor.surface_text: 5  that the counting of votes of Bhitauli Assembly Unit continued till 8-30 p.m. in insufficient light notwithstanding the protest lodged by the petitioner and

facts.text: Kidwai claimed on true count he would have majority of valid votes and entitled to be declared elected.

anchor.surface_text: 6  that on a true count he  Kidwai  would have received a majority of valid votes and that he was entitled to be declared duly elected.

facts.text: Allegations denied by Yadav.

anchor.surface_text: These allegations were denied by Yadav.

facts.text: Election Tribunal held pleas 3,4,5 failed as no evidence led by Kidwai.

anchor.surface_text: In respect of the pleas  3 ,  4  and  5  the burden of proof lay upon Kidwai and as no evidence was led to substantiate the same, those pleas failed.

facts.text: Tribunal held Kidwai failed to prove discrepancies between Forms 16 and 20 as originals not called for.

anchor.surface_text: Again in the view of the Tribunal, Kidwai could discharge the burden of proof which lay upon him to establish that there were discrepancies ,between the original and the certified copies of Forms Nos 16 20, and as the original forms were not called for by Kidwai, his second ground must also fail.

facts.text: Kidwai applied for inspection of ballot papers; Tribunal rejected holding prima facie case needed.

anchor.surface_text: Kidwai claimed that he would be able to establish his case on pleas  1   6  from the ballot papers, and submitted that an order for inspection of the ballot papers be made ... The Tribunal rejected the application for inspection holding that ballot papers may be allowed to be inspected only if it is necessary in the interest of justice...

facts.text: Ballot papers lodged before Tribunal by Returning Officer on oral request by Kidwai.

anchor.surface_text: In this case, on an oral request made by Kidwai all the ballot papers in sealed boxes were lodged with the Election Tribunal.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Tribunal did not err in refusing inspection of ballot papers as no prima facie case made out.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to this infirmity the Tribunal was justified in declining to make an order for inspection of the ballot papers unless a prima facie case was made out in support of the claim.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 23, 1963, of the Allahabad High Court  Lucknow

concepts.unlisted_description: Limits challenges to elections to election petitions.

anchor.surface_text: states what the election petition shall contain. It states An election petition- a shall contain a concise statement of the material facts on which the petitioner relies 159 S.C-16 b shall set forth full particulars of any corrupt practice that the petitioner alleges, including as full a statement as posssible of the names of the parties alleged to have committed such corrupt practice and the date and place of the commission of each such practice and c shall be signed by the petitioner and verified in the manner laid down in the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, for the verification of pleadings The rest of the section is not material.

concepts.interpretation: Requires election petition to contain concise statement of material facts; vague averments do not comply.

anchor.surface_text: Section 92 enumerates the powers which a Tribunal trying an election petition may exercise and the powers so enumerated are the powers which a Court under the Code of Civil Procedure, when trying a suit, may exercise in respect of discovery and inspection, enforcing attendance of witnesses, compelling production of documents, receiving evidence taken on affidavits and issuing commissions for the examination of witnesses.

concepts.interpretation: Tribunal has civil court powers re discovery, inspection, production etc.

anchor.surface_text: By rule 93 of the Conduct of Election Rules, 1961, it is provided that While in the custody of the returning officer- a the packets of unused ballot papers b the packets of used ballot papers whether valid, tendered or rejected c the packets of the marked copy of the electoral roll or, as the case may be, the list maintained under sub-section 1 or sub- section 2 of section 152 and d the packets of the declarations by electors and the attestation of their signatures shall not be opened and their contents shall not be inspected by, or produced before, any person or authority except under the order of a competent court or tribunal.

concepts.interpretation: Ballot papers can only be inspected under order of competent court or tribunal; distinguishes from other papers open to inspection.

holdings.text: The Election Tribunal did not err in declining to grant an order for inspection of the ballot papers.

anchor.surface_text: The only question which falls to be determined in this appeal is whether the Election Tribunal erred in declining to grant an order for inspection of the ballot papers which had been, pursuant to its order in that behalf,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petition lacked concise statement of material facts under s.83(1)(a); no prima facie case shown; justified refusal to prevent fishing expedition.

holdings.text: An election petition must contain a concise statement of the material facts on which the petitioner relies as required by Section 83(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: Section 80 of the Act provides that no election shall be called in question except by an election petition presented in accordance with the provisions of Part VI. Section 83 1  states what the election

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory requirement; vague averments do not comply; necessary for inspection orders.

holdings.text: The Tribunal has power to order inspection of ballot papers apart from Order XI CPC, implicit in Sections 100(1)(d)(iii), 101, 102 and Rule 93.

anchor.surface_text: Section 90 1 prescribes the procedure to be followed by the Tribunal. It states Subject to the provisions of this Act and of any rules made thereunder, every election petition shall be tried by the Tribunal, as nearly as may be, in accordance with the procedure applicable under the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, to the trial of suits

holdings.reasoning_summary: Powers under s.92 and specific provisions allow calling for ballot papers when interests of justice demand.

holdings.text: Mere production of sealed ballot boxes before the Tribunal does not entitle to inspection; they do not become part of the record automatically.

anchor.surface_text: By rule 93 of the Conduct of Election Rules, 1961, it is provided that While in the custody of the returning officer- a the packets of unused ballot papers b the packets of used ballot papers whether valid, tendered or rejected c the packets of the marked copy of the electoral roll or, as the case may be, the list maintained under sub-section 1 or sub- section 2 of section 152 and

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inspection only if necessary in interests of justice; Rule 93 requires court order.

holdings.text: Order for inspection of ballot papers cannot be granted as a matter of course due to secrecy of ballot under ss.94 and 128(1).

anchor.surface_text: subject to the statutory restrictions about the secrecy of the ballot paper prescribed by ss. 94 and 128 1 . An order for inspection may not be granted as a matter of course having regard to the insistence upon the secrecy of the ballot papers,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Secrecy principle restricts access; discretionary only if conditions met.

holdings.text: Inspection justified only if: (1) petition contains adequate material facts; (2) prima facie necessity in interests of justice.

anchor.surface_text: having regard to the insistence upon the secrecy of the ballot papers, the Court would be justified in granting an order for inspection provided two conditions are fulfilled that the petition for setting aside an election contains an adequate statement of the material facts on which the petitioner relies in support of his case and the Tribunal is prima facie satisfied that in order to decide the dispute and to do complete justice between the parties inspection of the ballot papers is necessary,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Two-prong test balancing secrecy, justice; not routine.

holdings.text: Inspection cannot be granted to support vague pleas or as a fishing expedition.

anchor.surface_text: But an order for inspection of ballot papers cannot be granted to support vague pleas made in the petition not supported by material facts or to fish out evidence to support such pleas.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petition must plead precise facts; candidates had opportunity at counting to know specifics.

holdings.text: Kidwai's averments in petition were vague and did not comply with s.83(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: These averments in the petition for setting aside the election on the ground of improper acceptance or rejection of votes were vague, and did not comply with the statutory requirements of s. 83 1 a .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Specific paras 6H,6K,12 lacked material facts within petitioner's knowledge.

holdings.text: Bhim Sen case does not entitle inspection without material facts or prima facie case.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished on facts: concerned amendment after inspection, not right to inspect without basis.

precedents.citation: Bhim Sen v. Gopali and others 1

anchor.surface_text: Bhim Sen v. Gopali and others 1  in support of the plea that mere absence of parti- culars will number furnish a ground for declining to grant ins

precedents.cited_proposition: mere absence of particulars will not furnish a ground for declining to grant inspection and that a defeated candidate is entitled to establish his case that void votes had been counted and included in the votes of the successful candidate from the evidence collected from inspection of the ballot papers
precedents.cited_holding: definite particulars about the number and nature of the void votes that had been counted could only be supplied after inspection of the ballot papers and the election petition as originally presented must therefore be regarded as having furnished the material particulars and the amendment petition must be treated merely as an application for clarification of the pleadings

anchor.surface_text: 22 E.L.R. 288. was that it was incumbent upon the Returning Officer to go into each case of double voting in order to reject one of the two votes cast in companytravention of s. 63 1  of the Representation of the People Act, and that the Returning Officer having failed to discharge his duty to reject ballot papers cast in companytravention of s. 63 the petitioner believed that the successful candidate companyld receive many void votes.

precedents.cited_proposition: definite particulars about the number and nature of the void votes that had been counted could only be supplied after inspection of the ballot papers

anchor.surface_text: In Bhim Sens case 1  a petition was filed for setting aside an election of a candidate in a reserved seat in a double member companystituency. The principal ground in support of the petition 1  22 E.L.R. 288. was that it was incumbent upon the Returning Officer to go into each case of double voting

precedents.cited_proposition: in a case where definite particulars about void votes could only be supplied after inspection, the original petition furnished material particulars and amendment was clarification

anchor.surface_text: In Bhim Sens case 1  the Court was primarily companycerned with the question whether amendment of the petition to set aside an election should be granted. It was alleged by the defeated candidate that there had been companytravention of the provisions of s. 63  1   of the Act by the Returning Officer and the election was materially affected on that account.

precedents.cited_proposition: the Court was primarily concerned with whether amendment of the petition should be granted after inspection revealed void votes

anchor.surface_text: 22 E.L.R.288. stated, he cannot be permitted to make out a case by fishing out the evidence from an inspection of the ballot papers. In Bhim Sens case 1  the Court was number companycerned to decide whether the order for inspection was properly made the propriety of the order granting inspection does number appear to have ever been questioned.

precedents.cited_proposition: the observation about particulars being supplied after inspection was not intended as a general statement of law allowing inspection without specific allegations

anchor.surface_text: But an order for inspection of ballot papers cannot be granted to support vague pleas made in the petition not supported by material facts or to fish out evidence to support such pleas.
Having regard to this infirmity the Tribunal was justified in declining to make an order for inspection of the ballot papers unless a prima facie case was made out in support of the claim.
These averments in the petition for setting aside the election on the ground of improper acceptance or rejection of votes were vague, and did not comply with the statutory requirements of s. 83 1 a .
